Award.AwardTitle: CRII: III: Evaluating Provenance Visualizations for the Presentation and Communication of Investigative Data Analysis Processes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many types of data analysis involve complex investigations with large data sets, open-ended explorations, and iterative hypothesis testing. The high complexity and potential variability in human analytic processing can make it difficult to remember the steps and rationale that led to the formation of hypotheses, the generation of specific data views, and the realization of conclusions. There is an established need for reviewing analytic processes, and many tools provide visualizations to do so; however, it is not well known how helpful the tools are for practical purposes. In particular, little visualization research has evaluated the effectiveness of visual representations for the purposes of communication and presentation of analysis history. The project will explore new designs for visually representing the history of data analysis and evaluating the effectiveness of different designs. The outcomes of the visualization designs and empirical evaluations will yield direct benefits to professional analysts and scientists by improving the ability to review and communicate analysis records. Effective presentation and communication of analytic processes is essential for understanding the underlying arguments behind decisions, and visual presentation will facilitate review of analysis processes by making it possible to understand analytics strategies and their effectiveness. Reviewing analysis approaches and strategies will allow analysts to identify problems with existing methods, improve those methods, and better train new analysts and scientists.

This project will provide the foundation for an extensive effort of the design and evaluation of visualizations for the presentation and communication of the history of an analysis process, which is also known as analytic provenance. Through the development of new evaluation methodology, the project will enable the assessment of how well specific visual elements of provenance visualizations contribute to successful presentation of different types of provenance information. The effort will include detailed collection and coding of samples of provenance data that will be used as a basis for evaluating visualizations. The research will explore novel visualization designs for presenting different types of captured information. In addition, the effort will investigate methods to automatically generate provenance visualization, and it will study the effectiveness of different forms of automated presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many aspects of our society depend on the collection and interpretation of data for human interpretation and decision making. For example, maintaining knowledge and making action for financial, scientific, and national security purposes all require continuous data analysis involving complex investigations with large data sets and open-ended explorations. Unfortunately, the high complexity of data exploration can make it difficult to remember the steps and rationale that led to the results, the generation of specific data views, and the realization of conclusions. This can be a major problem for transparency, verification, and workplace communication. There is an established need for reviewing analytic processes, and many tools provide visualizations to do so; however, it is not well known how helpful the tools are for practical purposes. In particular, little visualization research has evaluated the effectiveness of visual representations for the purposes of communication and presentation of analysis history.

The research project investigated new designs for visually representing the history of data analysis and evaluating the effectiveness of different types of presentation. The outcomes of the visualization designs and scientific studies can help professional analysts and scientists by improving the ability to review and communicate analysis records. Effective presentation and communication of analytic processes is essential for understanding the underlying arguments behind decisions, and visual presentation will facilitate review of analysis processes by making it possible to understand analytics strategies and their effectiveness. Reviewing analysis approaches and strategies will allow analysts to identify problems with existing methods, improve those methods, and better train new analysts and scientists.

The project provides a foundation for the design and evaluation of visualizations for the presentation and communication of the history of data analysis history (which is also called analytic provenance). Through the development of new evaluation methodology, the project contributed new data processing techniques to help automatically produce visualizations to help understand data analysis activities. Through detailed collection and review of sample provenance data, the research also provided publicly available datasets that can be used by new researchers as the basis for designing and evaluating new visualization designs.

Additionally, the project included a study of analyst needs and current use of data tools in professional analysis environments (i.e., government and private sector) to provide valuable information about practical needs and challenges for applying the results of this research in real-world settings. The research outcomes and study findings have been published in numerous scholarly papers and presented at international research meetings, and all research outcomes are publicly available online. Furthermore, the research team directly shared and discussed the research progress with two research labs for the US Department of Energy (specifically, Pacific-Northwest National Laboratory and Oak Ridge National Laboratory). Both national labs have analysts and data scientists working on a wide array of research challenges for protecting and advancing national infrastructure, security, energy efficiency, scientific computation, and environmental systems. Interacting with experts in these areas directly increase the visibility of the outcomes while aiding application of scientific research outcomes to national challenges.

For example, maintaining knowledge and making action for financial, scientific, and national security purposes all require continuous data analysis involving complex investigations with large data sets and open-ended explorations. Unfortunately, the high complexity of data exploration can make it difficult to remember the steps and rationale that led to the results, the generation of specific data views, and the realization of conclusions. This can be a major problem for transparency, verification, and workplace communication. The project provides a foundation for the design and evaluation of visualizations for the presentation and communication of the history of data analysis history (which is also called analytic provenance). Additionally, the project included a study of analyst needs and current use of data tools in professional analysis environments (i.e., government and private sector) to provide valuable information about practical needs and challenges for applying the results of this research in real-world settings. The research outcomes and study findings have been published in numerous scholarly papers and presented at international research meetings, and all research outcomes are publicly available online. Furthermore, the research team directly shared and discussed the research progress with two research labs for the US Department of Energy (specifically, Pacific-Northwest National Laboratory and Oak Ridge National Laboratory).
